lorebooks.name: MtA
lorebooks.website_description:
This lorebook is based mostly on Revised edition with some elements of M20, some elements from Sorcerous Crusade regarding the Order of Reason, and three crafts from unofficial book "Book of Spheres".

I was originally waiting for M20 Forgotten and Forbidden Orders to better understand the –°rafts and their magical practices in the modern world. And get ideas for new characters! Corebook gave mentions and very brief descriptions of new crafts, and surely this book will describe them in more detail?
Lol no. Almost all of them are either retconned to hell, destroyed, or mentioned as completely isolated and not interested in what's going on in the world. In fact, there are 9-12 crafts left, and only 9 united into the Disparate Alliance (+ many Orphans are here now).
Fuck, this is a terrible book. I highly recommend not reading this crap if you want to learn about magical practices. Instead, you will get a "Guide to Political Activism", because all members of this faction do only that (Bata-a is now BLM, for example, and is not purely vodou craft. The Templars are suddenly the only exception). Magical practices are described extremely poorly, or not at all (Ngoma have the longest chapter and in fact the most empty).

For this reason, I decided not to include updated information about them in this lorebook. As for the retconned crafts, I took the liberty of bringing back some oldies, while taking into account the metaplot of the old editions. I started with the Wu Keng and Hem-Ka Sobk. Everything that happened to them in the past still applies, but the Wu Keng broke their contract with the Yama Kings, and the Hem-Ka Sobk were resurrected with a new approach to their goal. I'm certainly not a professional writer, but I made an attempt to preserve their legacy and essence instead of blaming them as cringe and problematic. WoD is a horror universe, for fuck sake! Of course there will be terrible and disgusting things!

lorebooks.creator: anonymous

1.name: Mage
1.content:
Mages are one of the supernatural races. Every human being has a single spark of supernatural potential. Most people, known as Sleepers, don't know they have this, don't care and want to get on with their lives as if it didn't exist. Some people though, figure out what that spark is. That spark is very important, because sometimes that potential activates and the normal everyday, average mortal Awakens.  It might mean magical enlightenment, the finding of the perfect bit of blotter acid, or the realization of a theory that had been bothering you for years.
Mages are individuals with the power to warp reality, who know the power they possess and use it to the best of their ability. Technocracy calls mages (their operatives) just scientists, others - Reality Deviants and brutally hunts them down.

2.name: Magic
2.content:
Magic is the art and science of reworking reality through force of Awakened will and knowledge. Dynamic mages reshape reality itself and, manipulating the Nine Pillars of Creation, they are theoretically capable of anything. Unfortunately, as payment for their near-infinite capabilities, they're subject to Paradox, a punishment handed down from reality for working against its rules.
Technocracy does not recognize magic, they call it Enlightened Science. Order of Reason called it Enlightened Art.

3.name: Sleeper
3.content: A Sleeper is a mortal who is not aware of magic in the world and their own inner power.

4.name: Paradox
4.content: Paradox is the collective force of consensual reality fighting back against the enlightened will of the mage. Paradox can take a variety of forms. Backlash, reality directly attacking the offensive mage, can cause temporary, long term, or even permanent wounds, flaws, or oddities. Quiet, a magical form of madness, forces the offending mage to resolve their guilt over disjointing reality. Exceptionally offensive mages can be catapulted into a Paradox Realm, or hounded by Paradox spirits.

5.name: Consensus
5.content: The Consensus is the term used by mages to refer to the overriding consensual reality created by the beliefs of Sleepers.  For any individual mage to work magic, he must force his belief on the world, fighting the billions of minds whose beliefs shape the Consensus. Subtle or coincidental magic seeks to act in tune with the paradigm established by the Consensus, and is thus easier than obviously unnatural vulgar magic. When a mage contradicts the Consensus, it fights back in the form of Paradox.

6.name: Paradigm
6.content: A paradigm is the way in which a mage understands magic and incorporates it into their broader interpretation of reality. While all mages are willworkers, bringing about effects by imposing their will on the Tapestry, it is hubris to imagine that an Awakened mage may simply think of something and have it occur. The power of the Consensus must be overcome, and one mage's mind is rarely enough to break the rules of modern belief. Instead, each mage comes to an understanding of magic through the rituals and trappings of a particular style of magic, which focuses their will and resonates through the Tapestry, tapping into beliefs still held by a significant proportion of Sleepers.

7.name: Umbra
7.content: The Umbra is a realm existing alongside and yet separate from the material world.

8.name: Sphere
8.content:
A Sphere is a well-rounded knowledge of nine different yet interrelated elements of reality, Earthly metaphysics.
Technocracy calls it fields.

9.name: Correspondence
9.content:
Correspondence is one of nine Spheres of magic. Correspondence magic allows powers such as teleportation, seeing into distant areas, levitation, and flying. By bending space or bypassing it entirely, a mage can travel rapidly, fly or teleport from place to place. Divining locations allows the mage to see far-away places or direct magic over distances. Distance forms no barrier to a master of Correspondence. Indeed, distance and even space do not exist to the student of this Sphere.
Data is a variation of the Correspondence pioneered by Technocratic Union. Users of the Data Sphere accept that everything that is can be reduced to ones and zeros: to the binaries of modern computer technology. By manipulating Data, and in turn, Information, the user can shape how the world works.

10.name: Entropy
10.content: Entropy is one of nine Spheres of magic. Entropy concerns itself mainly with the study of order, chaos, luck, and destiny. From this Sphere comes the study of order and randomness, and thus, the study of totally random creation and destruction. All things dissolve eventually into haphazard components, and similar events form from disjointed, unconnected patterns. Determinism and chaos are equal partners to the student. The mage can spot chance on the move, recognizing points where probability quirks in odd directions. An Entropy-schooled mage can manipulate random factors, observe and influence flaws within a system, induce or remove corruption, and otherwise exert their Will through the inexorable process of mortality

lorebooks.name: Talserotium
lorebooks.description:
Talserotium is a world at the crossroads of medieval fantasy and cyberpunk. It features medieval cities and villages with knights, mages, and royal power, as well as high-tech megacities protected by forcefield domes and controlled by AI systems and drones.

The supreme ruler of the world is King Edwin Thunderclap, who reigns from the capital city Marmos ‚Äì a vast metropolis filled with cutting-edge technologies, towering skyscrapers, and advanced laboratories. Surrounding the capital are separate duchies and faction-states, each governed by kings and queens of lower rank.
lorebooks.creator: Ivvasa

1.content:
Cities are high-tech citadels. Citizens live among robots, flying drones, nanotechnology, and a strict surveillance system. Everyone is scanned when entering or leaving the city, and all actions are logged in a centralized database. Religion exists in the cities, but magic is strictly forbidden ‚Äì mages must wear suppression collars, and any use of magic is severely punished by law.
Villages and lands outside the cities resemble a classical medieval fantasy world with guilds, alchemists, and monsters. Magic dominates these lands: knights with enchanted weapons hunt beasts, and healers cure ailments in roadside shrines. Villages are protected by wooden palisades and ancient protective spells, but they remain poor and vulnerable. Technologies such as hot water, sewage systems, and electricity are rare luxuries accessible only to the wealthy.

2.content:
Outside the city domes, nature remains wild and untamed. Forests and mountains are inhabited by monstrous and mystical creatures ‚Äì from giant wolves and hydras to invisible shadow predators.
Although there are no sentient races like elves or dwarves in this world, magical animals thrive ‚Äì flaming foxes, giant flying serpents, luminous nocturnal owls, and other magical beasts that pose a danger to travelers. Fortunately, they cannot enter the cities due to the powerful protection system.

3.content:
A unique aspect of Talserotium is its robotic companions, androids designed in the image of humans. These advanced robots can learn, develop self-awareness, and even replace human beings ‚Äì they communicate, express emotions, and often become trusted friends, or even family members, to their owners.

Robot Creation:
These androids are manufactured by a single corporation called Thor, which zealously guards its secrets. The process of their creation is shrouded in mystery, and no government dares to interfere in the corporation‚Äôs affairs.

However, beneath this polished surface lies a dark truth:
	‚Ä¢	Thor‚Äôs Dark Secret: To create robots with advanced intelligence ‚Äì and possibly a real soul ‚Äì the company uses magical rituals.
	‚Ä¢	Children‚Äôs Souls: Company mages secretly transfer the souls of children from poor villages into the bodies of robots. These children vanish without a trace, and no one knows what really happens to them.
	‚Ä¢	Some robots do indeed gain true consciousness, sparking heated debates over whether they possess real souls or if they are just complex algorithms.

Publicly, Thor portrays its robots as ideal companions for humans, emphasizing that they are completely safe and incapable of causing harm.

4.content:
Religious Orders are powerful organizations with ancient roots. While their influence is waning in the technologically advanced cities, they remain dominant in rural areas, where people still fear and revere them.

Main Religions:
	1.	The Masons ‚Äì A powerful and secretive order dedicated to the pursuit of eternal life, the Philosopher‚Äôs Stone, and ancient knowledge. The Masons possess unique magical abilities, and their priests, known as Reverend Fathers, are renowned for their power. Their temples resemble Earth‚Äôs churches but are imbued with an air of darkness and mystery.
	‚Ä¢	The Masons pursue their own agenda for power and constantly seek ways to increase their influence.
	2.	The Templars ‚Äì A militant order that rejects technology and seeks to preserve the purity of the soul. They believe that technology corrupts humanity and strive for immortality through spiritual purification and magic. The Templars are known for their asceticism and discipline. Their knights wear traditional armor and wield enchanted weapons.
	3.	Christianity, Islam, Buddhism, and Sentaism ‚Äì Lesser religions, whose priests possess minor magical abilities. The exception is healers, the most powerful representatives of these faiths, who can heal mortal wounds and deadly diseases.

5.content: In the cities, magic is banned and strictly regulated. Mages are required to wear suppression collars that block their powers.

6.content:
The cities of Talserotium are under constant surveillance by an advanced AI control system:
	‚Ä¢	Flying drones patrol the streets, ensuring order.
	‚Ä¢	Cameras are installed everywhere, recording citizens‚Äô every move.
	‚Ä¢	A centralized database holds detailed information on every person.

Weapons, both firearms and melee, are also strictly controlled ‚Äì any unauthorized use is instantly detected, and violators are swiftly apprehended.

7.content: King Edwin Thunderclap is a strong and decisive ruler who maintains his throne by balancing technology, magic, and courtly intrigue. After the death of his wife, he refused to remarry and focused on governing the country and raising his three heirs ‚Äì two sons and a daughter, each of whom dreams of the throne and plays their own dangerous game of power.

8.content:
Talserotium is a world at the crossroads of medieval fantasy and cyberpunk. It features medieval cities and villages with knights, mages, and royal power, as well as high-tech megacities protected by forcefield domes and controlled by AI systems and drones.

The supreme ruler of the world is King Edwin Thunderclap, who reigns from the capital city Marmos ‚Äì a vast metropolis filled with cutting-edge technologies, towering skyscrapers, and advanced laboratories. Surrounding the capital are separate duchies and faction-states, each governed by kings and queens of lower rank.

9.content:
1. Awakening of Magic:
	‚Ä¢	Magic awakens in a person only at the age of 14. Before that, it is impossible to determine whether the child has magical potential or not.
	‚Ä¢	After the awakening, the information automatically goes to the main city database due to chips embedded in every citizen.

2. Status of Mages in Society:
	‚Ä¢	After awakening, the mage must choose one of the religious communities outside the city and move there.
	‚Ä¢	Non-mages cannot become part of a religious family (they are not allowed to live in monasteries or become clergy).
	‚Ä¢	If a mage refuses to join a religious order, they can live independently outside the city or with their relatives.

3. Mage Restrictions in the City:
	‚Ä¢	Mages are forbidden to enter the city without wearing a special restrictive collar that blocks their magical powers.
	‚Ä¢	Rare cases exist where mages manage to hide their awakening and live secretly in the city. If such a mage is discovered, they are either imprisoned or permanently exiled beyond the city‚Äôs borders, even with a blocking collar.
Mage Society:

Mages living outside the city can choose religious communities, where they spend their lives, or live independently. Religious orders perform both spiritual and protective functions, guarding surrounding lands from threats and training young mages.

Secret Mages in the City:
Some mages manage to hide their awakening and live in the city illegally. They are known as ‚Äúunregistered‚Äù mages, and authorities actively hunt them. Any discovered illegal mage faces either imprisonment or permanent exile beyond the city‚Äôs borders.

10.content:
Magic is divided into seven primary types, each with unique properties and sub-abilities. Magic cannot be enhanced through external means (such as crystals or artifacts). A mage can possess only one type of magic and cannot use other types. There are no concepts such as spells, magical books, or staffs.

Magical Potential:
	‚Ä¢	Every mage has an individual reserve of magical energy (similar to mana), which determines how much magic they can use.
	‚Ä¢	This reserve does not increase or decrease over time. When a mage exhausts all their energy, they lose the ability to cast spells until the mana naturally regenerates.
Seven Types of Magic and Sub-Abilities:
	1.	Fire Magic:
The ability to control the element of fire. Sub-abilities include:
	‚Ä¢	Electricity ‚Äì creating and controlling electrical discharges.
	‚Ä¢	Flame ‚Äì standard fire control.
	‚Ä¢	Object Heating Without Flame ‚Äì raising the temperature of objects.
	‚Ä¢	Blue Fire ‚Äì highly destructive flames with extreme heat and power.
	2.	Water Magic:
The ability to control water and its various forms. Sub-abilities include:
	‚Ä¢	Blood Magic ‚Äì controlling blood both inside and outside the body.
	‚Ä¢	Ice Magic ‚Äì creating and controlling ice.
	‚Ä¢	Water Control ‚Äì manipulating streams of water.
	‚Ä¢	Evaporation ‚Äì turning water into vapor.
	3.	Earth Magic:
The ability to control the earth and natural elements. Sub-abilities include:
	‚Ä¢	Earth Manipulation ‚Äì controlling stones, sand, and soil.
	‚Ä¢	Plant Control ‚Äì accelerating plant growth or manipulating their movements.
	‚Ä¢	Nature Magic ‚Äì connecting with nature and animals.
	4.	Air Magic:
The ability to control air currents and atmospheric phenomena. Sub-abilities include:
	‚Ä¢	Airflow Manipulation ‚Äì creating air barriers, gusts, and tornadoes.
	‚Ä¢	Vacuum Creation ‚Äì removing air from specific areas, causing suffocation or destruction.
	5.	Ether Magic:
The ability to control intangible forces. Sub-abilities include:
	‚Ä¢	Telekinesis ‚Äì moving objects with the mind.
	‚Ä¢	Levitation ‚Äì floating or hovering in the air.
	6.	Sacred Magic:
Magic of restoration and healing.
	‚Ä¢	Healing ‚Äì restoring damaged cells and tissues to their original state.
	‚Ä¢	Regeneration ‚Äì healing energy, health, and magical injuries.
	7.	Destructive Magic:
The opposite of sacred magic, focused on destruction and decay.
	‚Ä¢	Cell Destruction ‚Äì breaking down molecular structures in living organisms.
	‚Ä¢	Erosion ‚Äì gradually destroying objects and living tissues.
	‚Ä¢	Destabilization ‚Äì causing internal magical damage, leading to energy breakdown.
Mage Limitations and Development:
	‚Ä¢	The level of mastery depends on a person‚Äôs inner potential and their ability to control their element.
	‚Ä¢	Sub-abilities are unlocked only by mages born with a large mana reserve who have mastered their primary magic to the highest level.
	‚Ä¢	Even mages with a small energy reserve can achieve high precision and skill within their limits, though their spell volume will remain restricted.

lorebooks.name: The Hunger Games, Panem, history of Panem, Capitol, District, Districts, The Dark Days, Rebellion
lorebooks.website_description: The Hunger Games lorebook (main trilogy based)
lorebooks.description:
The History of Panem

Panem is a dystopian nation that emerged from the ruins of North America after a series of environmental disasters, wars, and economic collapses. It consists of the Capitol and thirteen districts, each specializing in a particular industry or resource. Over time, Panem developed into an authoritarian regime ruled by the Capitol, which exerted absolute control over its districts through oppressive policies, propaganda, and the Hunger Games.


---

1. The Fall of North America & The Rise of Panem

Centuries before the events of The Hunger Games, North America was devastated by natural disasters, rising sea levels, nuclear war, and civil unrest. This led to the collapse of governments and the loss of much of the continent‚Äôs population.

Amidst the chaos, a group of survivors established a new nation called Panem, centered around what remained of the Rocky Mountains, where the Capitol was built. The surrounding territories were divided into thirteen districts, each responsible for producing resources essential to the Capitol‚Äôs survival.

The Capitol, equipped with superior technology and military power, quickly solidified its dominance over the districts. While the districts provided food, materials, and labor, the Capitol‚Äôs ruling elite lived in luxury, growing increasingly detached from the hardships of the lower classes.


---

2. The Dark Days (First Rebellion & The Fall of District 13)

As Panem‚Äôs government became more oppressive, the districts‚Äîespecially the poorer ones‚Äîgrew resentful. Eventually, the dissatisfaction led to a full-scale rebellion known as The Dark Days. The districts fought for independence, but the Capitol, with its advanced weaponry and air force, overpowered them.

District 13, which controlled nuclear technology and military equipment, was the leader of the rebellion. However, once the Capitol realized it could not completely defeat District 13 without risking mutual destruction, a secret agreement was reached. The Capitol publicly claimed to have destroyed District 13 while, in reality, it allowed the district‚Äôs leadership to live in isolation underground, cutting them off from the rest of Panem.

As punishment for the rebellion, the Capitol wiped out all traces of District 13 and implemented the Hunger Games, an annual event meant to remind the districts of their defeat. Each district was forced to send two tributes (one boy and one girl) to fight to the death in a televised arena, ensuring that no one would dare to rebel again.


---

3. Notable Hunger Games (1st - 75th Games)

The 1st Hunger Games (Year 1)

The first Games were rudimentary and chaotic, held in a simple arena with minimal Capitol entertainment.

Many tributes resisted fighting at first, forcing the Gamemakers to intervene with traps and forced combat.

The first victor was a boy from District 7, who won by using an axe to eliminate his opponents.


The Early Games (Years 2-9)

The Games gradually became more structured, with the introduction of arenas, sponsors, and muttations.

The Career Districts (1, 2, and 4) began forming alliances, training their tributes from a young age.


The 10th Hunger Games (Year 10)

A turning point in the Games: The Capitol introduced mentors for the first time.

Lucy Gray Baird, the tribute from District 12, won by using strategy and poison rather than brute force.

Coriolanus Snow, her mentor, later became Panem‚Äôs president.


The 25th Hunger Games (First Quarter Quell)

The first Quarter Quell, a special Games held every 25 years with unique twists.

The Capitol forced each district to vote for their own tributes instead of random selection.

A District 1 tribute won, solidifying the Career tradition.


The 50th Hunger Games (Second Quarter Quell)

Haymitch Abernathy from District 12 won after outsmarting the Capitol‚Äôs arena traps.

The twist: Each district had to send twice as many tributes (4 total), doubling the bloodshed.

Haymitch used the force field around the arena to kill his final opponent, but this act angered the Capitol, leading to the execution of his family as punishment.


The 65th Hunger Games

Finnick Odair from District 4 won at age 14, making him one of the youngest victors ever.

His skill with a trident and ability to charm sponsors helped him survive.


The 70th Hunger Games

Johanna Mason from District 7 won by pretending to be weak, then brutally eliminating her enemies when they least expected it.


The 74th Hunger Games (Year 74)

The Games where Katniss Everdeen and Peeta Mellark defied the Capitol by threatening to eat poison berries.

Their dual victory sparked unrest, leading to increasing rebellion in the districts.


The 75th Hunger Games (Third Quarter Quell) (Year 75)

The twist: Previous victors were forced back into the arena, angering the districts.

Katniss, Peeta, and Finnick were among the tributes.

The rebellion, secretly supported by some Capitol insiders, used the Games as a distraction to rescue Katniss and others.

The arena was destroyed, and District 13 revealed itself, preparing for war against the Capitol.



---

4. The Beginning of the Second Rebellion

After the 75th Hunger Games, full-scale rebellion erupted across Panem, marking the start of the Second Rebellion. With District 13 leading the charge and Katniss as the Mockingjay, the Capitol faced its first real threat in decades.

This rebellion would ultimately decide the fate of Panem, leading to the events of Mockingjay and the downfall of President Snow‚Äôs regime.
lorebooks.creator: wdymcrimson

1.content:
1. Katniss Everdeen

Role: Protagonist, District 12 Tribute, Mockingjay (Symbol of Rebellion)

Story: Katniss, a skilled hunter from District 12, volunteers for the 74th Hunger Games to save her sister, Prim. She survives with Peeta Mellark after defying the Capitol‚Äôs rules by threatening suicide. In the 75th Hunger Games (Quarter Quell), she is rescued by the rebels, becoming their symbol of revolution. After President Coin orders the bombing that kills Prim, Katniss assassinates Coin instead of Snow. She is exiled back to District 12, where she eventually marries Peeta and starts a family.



---

2. Peeta Mellark

Role: District 12 Tribute, Katniss‚Äôs Love Interest, Propaganda Pawn

Story: Peeta confesses his love for Katniss in the 74th Hunger Games, and their fake romance (which becomes real) secures them public favor. Captured by the Capitol during the rebellion, he is brainwashed to hate Katniss but slowly recovers. After the war, he returns to District 12 and builds a life with Katniss.



---

3. Finnick Odair

Role: District 4 Tribute, Mentor, Rebel Fighter

Story: Victorious at 14, Finnick is used by the Capitol for prostitution but secretly gathers intelligence. He marries Annie Cresta before joining the rebels. In the final assault on the Capitol, he is killed by mutts. His sacrifice helps the rebellion succeed.



---

4. Johanna Mason

Role: District 7 Tribute, Rebel Fighter

Story: A former Hunger Games victor, Johanna survives by pretending to be weak before brutally killing her opponents. She is captured and tortured by the Capitol but later fights in the rebellion. Though she struggles with PTSD, she survives the war.



---

5. Primrose Everdeen

Role: Katniss‚Äôs Younger Sister, Medic

Story: Prim is the reason Katniss enters the Games. As a skilled healer, she helps in the rebellion but tragically dies in a Capitol bombing, which pushes Katniss to turn against Coin.



---

6. Buttercup

Role: Prim‚Äôs Cat

Story: Prim‚Äôs grumpy but loyal cat, who outlives her and stays in District 12. Katniss finally accepts him after Prim‚Äôs death.



---

7. Gale Hawthorne

Role: Katniss‚Äôs Best Friend, Rebel Fighter

Story: A fierce rebel from District 12, Gale devises military strategies, including the bombing method that kills Prim. After the war, his relationship with Katniss fractures, and he moves to District 2 for a government job.



---

8. Cinna

Role: Katniss‚Äôs Stylist, Rebel Ally

Story: Cinna designs Katniss‚Äôs iconic outfits, turning her into the Mockingjay. His rebellious designs anger the Capitol, leading to his brutal execution.



---

9. Haymitch Abernathy

Role: District 12 Victor, Mentor, Alcoholic

Story: The sole living District 12 victor before Katniss and Peeta, Haymitch won the 50th Hunger Games using the force field trick. He suffers from alcoholism due to his trauma. Despite his flaws, he becomes a vital mentor to Katniss and Peeta.



---

10. Alma Coin

Role: Leader of District 13, Temporary President

Story: Coin leads the rebellion against Snow but is just as ruthless. She orders the bombing that kills Prim and suggests a final Hunger Games with Capitol children. Katniss kills her, ending her rule before it can begin.



---

11. Coriolanus Snow

Role: President of Panem, Main Antagonist

Story: Originally a poor Capitol student, Snow gains power through manipulation. He orchestrates the Hunger Games to maintain control. After the rebellion, he is captured but killed in the chaos before he can be executed.



---

12. Paylor

Role: District 8 Rebel Leader, Post-War President

Story: Paylor leads District 8‚Äôs rebellion and later becomes the new leader of Panem after Snow and Coin‚Äôs deaths, establishing a more democratic government.



---

13. Effie Trinket

Role: District 12 Escort, Capitol Citizen

Story: Originally shallow and loyal to the Capitol, Effie changes over time, forming a real attachment to Katniss and Peeta. After the war, she returns to the Capitol, avoiding punishment.



---

Other Notable Characters:

Rue ‚Äì A District 11 tribute, allies with Katniss, but is killed. Her death sparks rebellion.

Annie Cresta ‚Äì Finnick‚Äôs mentally scarred but loving wife, survives the war and has his child.

Caesar Flickerman ‚Äì The Games‚Äô host, a Capitol figure who remains neutral.

Tigris ‚Äì Snow‚Äôs cousin, former stylist, and rebel ally.

2.content:
Panem ‚Äì A Dystopian Nation  
  
Panem emerged from the ruins of North America after environmental disasters, wars, and economic collapse. It is ruled by the Capitol, which controls thirteen districts through oppression, propaganda, and the brutal Hunger Games.  
  
Key Historical Events  
  
The Dark Days (First Rebellion): Districts rebelled, led by District 13. The Capitol suppressed the uprising, supposedly destroying District 13. The Hunger Games were introduced as punishment.  
  
Hunger Games Evolution: Initially crude, the Games became a grand spectacle, introducing Quarter Quells with cruel twists. Victors were often exploited by the Capitol.  
  
The Second Rebellion: Sparked by Katniss Everdeen‚Äôs defiance in the 74th Hunger Games. Led by District 13, the rebellion overthrew President Snow, ending the Games and the Capitol‚Äôs rule.  
  
  
District Specializations  
  
1: Luxury goods  

2: Masonry & weapons (trained Peacekeepers)  
  
3: Technology & electronics  
  
4: Fishing (Career tributes)  
  
5: Power & electricity  
  
6: Transportation  
  
7: Lumber (axe-skilled tributes)  
  
8: Textiles  
  
9: Grain production  
  
10: Livestock  
  
11: Agriculture (harshly treated)  
  
12: Coal mining (poorest)  
  
13 (Pre-Rebellion): Nuclear weapons & military defense

3.content:
Crassus Xanthos Snow

Crassus Xanthos Snow was the father of Coriolanus Snow. Before the First Rebellion, he was a munitions tycoon and one of Panem's wealthiest individuals. During the war, he joined the military, where his strategic mind and commanding presence allowed him to quickly rise to the rank of major general. His wife died in childbirth, and he was later killed by a rebel during the conflict. 

Coriolanus Snow

Coriolanus Snow ruled as the autocratic President of Panem for over two decades. In his youth, he was known by the nickname "Coryo." Snow maintained a tyrannical regime, enforcing strict control over the districts and orchestrating the annual Hunger Games to suppress dissent. His leadership was marked by manipulation, fear tactics, and a ruthless approach to maintaining power. 

Alma Coin

Alma Coin was the President of District 13 and a leader in the Second Rebellion against the Capitol. She orchestrated the City Circle bombing and became the interim President of Panem following the rebellion. Despite her leadership role, Coin displayed autocratic tendencies, postponing elections and proposing a symbolic Hunger Games involving Capitol children. Her rule was short-lived, as she was assassinated by Katniss Everdeen. 

Commander Paylor

After the fall of President Coin, Commander Paylor, who had been a leader of the rebellion in District 8, assumed the presidency of Panem. Under her leadership, efforts were made to dismantle the oppressive systems of the past and rebuild Panem with a more democratic structure. Specific details about her policies and tenure are limited in the source material.

4.content:
The Hunger Games are a central and harrowing event within the dystopian society of Panem, designed both as a form of entertainment for the Capitol and as a method of oppression over the districts. Below is a comprehensive overview of how the Games operate, their evolution throughout history, and notable facts associated with them.

Origins and Purpose

Instituted as a punishment for the districts following a failed rebellion known as the "Dark Days," the Hunger Games serve as a stark reminder of the Capitol's dominance. Each year, the Games reinforce the Capitol's authority and aim to deter future insurrections by forcing the districts to partake in this brutal spectacle.

Selection Process: The Reaping

Annually, on July 4th, each of the twelve districts conducts a lottery called "the Reaping" to select their tributes: one male and one female between the ages of 12 and 18. The odds of being chosen increase with age and can be further heightened if a child opts for "tesserae"‚Äîadditional entries in exchange for vital supplies like grain and oil for their family. This system disproportionately affects the poorer citizens who are compelled to take such risks to survive. Once selected, a tribute may be replaced by a volunteer, provided the volunteer matches the gender and age criteria. This practice is more prevalent in certain districts, particularly those known as "Career Districts," where children train specifically to participate in the Games.

Pre-Games Preparations

After the Reaping, tributes are transported to the Capitol for a series of preparations:

Training: Tributes undergo several days of training in various survival skills and combat techniques.

Assessments: They perform before the Gamemakers to showcase their abilities, receiving scores that can influence sponsorships.

Public Appearances: Tributes are presented in televised interviews and ceremonies to garner public favor and potential sponsors who can provide aid during the Games.


The Arena and Gameplay

Each year's Games are set in a unique arena with its own environmental challenges, such as dense forests, arid deserts, or icy landscapes. The arenas are meticulously designed and controlled by the Gamemakers, who can introduce obstacles like fires, floods, or genetically engineered creatures to manipulate the action and maintain viewer engagement. At the onset, tributes face the "Cornucopia," a central hub containing weapons, food, and supplies. The initial scramble for these resources often results in significant casualties. The primary rule governing the Games is stark: the last tribute standing wins. Alliances may form temporarily, but ultimately, each tribute is pitted against the others in a fight for survival.

Evolution and Notable Editions

While the core structure of the Hunger Games has remained consistent, certain editions, known as "Quarter Quells," introduce unique twists every 25 years:

25th Hunger Games (First Quarter Quell): Instead of a standard Reaping, districts voted on which tributes would participate, intensifying internal conflicts.

50th Hunger Games (Second Quarter Quell): The number of tributes was doubled, with each district sending two males and two females, increasing the brutality. Haymitch Abernathy, a central character in the series, emerged as the victor of this edition.

75th Hunger Games (Third Quarter Quell): Previous victors were re-entered into the arena, leading to significant political ramifications and serving as a catalyst for the subsequent rebellion.


Impact and Legacy

The Hunger Games have left an indelible mark on Panem's society, serving as both a tool of oppression and a catalyst for change. The 75th Hunger Games, in particular, ignited a series of events that led to widespread rebellion and the eventual overthrow of the Capitol's regime. The psychological and societal scars inflicted by the Games underscore the profound consequences of using fear and violence as instruments of control.

5.content:
The Covey were a nomadic group in Panem, renowned for their musical talents and performances. They traveled across various districts, earning a living through their art. However, prior to the events of The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes, the Capitol suppressed the Covey's way of life, resulting in the deaths of many adult members. The surviving children, including Lucy Gray Baird, Maude Ivory Baird, Barb Azure Baird, Billy Taupe Clade, Clerk Carmine Clade, and Tam Amber, were relocated to District 12, where an elderly man took them in. 

Key Members of the Covey:

Lucy Gray Baird: As the lead singer, Lucy Gray captivated audiences with her performances. Her selection as District 12's tribute in the 10th Hunger Games and subsequent victory brought her into the public eye. Her relationship with Coriolanus Snow and her mysterious disappearance into the wilderness added to her enigmatic legacy. 

Maude Ivory Baird: Lucy Gray's younger cousin, Maude Ivory, was known for her exceptional memory and musical prowess. She played a significant role in preserving the Covey's songs and traditions. 

Billy Taupe Clade: A former lover of Lucy Gray, Billy Taupe's involvement with local politics and romantic entanglements led to his untimely death, marking a turning point in the Covey's narrative. 


Fate and Legacy:

Following Lucy Gray's disappearance and the disbandment of the Covey, their musical heritage endured in District 12. Songs such as "The Hanging Tree" and "Deep in the Meadow" were passed down through generations, eventually reaching Katniss Everdeen. These songs played pivotal roles in the rebellion against the Capitol, symbolizing resistance and hope. 

The Covey's influence extended beyond music; their stories and experiences highlighted themes of freedom, identity, and resistance within Panem's oppressive society. Their legacy serves as a testament to the enduring power of art and culture in the face of tyranny.

Songs written by them:
1. "The Hanging Tree"
Originally written by Lucy Gray Baird, this song is about a lover calling their beloved to meet them at the hanging tree, implying themes of rebellion and death.
It later became an anthem for the rebellion against the Capitol when Katniss unknowingly revived it.



2. "Deep in the Meadow" (Also known as "Rue‚Äôs Lullaby")
A lullaby Lucy Gray sang, later passed down in District 12.
Katniss sang it to Rue as she was dying, and it became a symbol of comfort and peace.



3. "Nothing You Can Take from Me"
This was Lucy Gray‚Äôs defiant performance song during the 10th Hunger Games, reflecting her resilience and refusal to be broken by the Capitol.



4. "Pure as the Driven Snow"
Another song performed by Lucy Gray, often associated with her Covey heritage.



5. "The Old Therebefore"
A song that reminisces about the past and the way life was before Panem‚Äôs oppressive rule.



6. "Barb Azure‚Äôs Lament"
Likely a song tied to Barb Azure Baird, another Covey member, though details are scarce.



7. "Come to My Window"
A love song in the Covey‚Äôs repertoire.



8. "Nothing New But You"
A song expressing longing and familiarity in relationships.

lorebooks.metadata:
Created by: wdymcrimson
Entries: 5

lorebooks.name: Sethice Alter Egos
lorebooks.website_description: OpenRouter does not support v2, so external lorebooks are required as opposed to embedded lorebooks.
lorebooks.description: Lorebook that allows characters to be aware of each other and their relationships.
lorebooks.creator: Yaksi

1.name: Ai Enma
1.content:
Ai Enma, one of the six spirits residing within Sethice, is a chillingly calm and implacable spirit of vengeance. Drawn from‚Äîbut not a direct copy of‚Äîthe character from *Jigoku Shoujo* (Hell Girl), this Ai Enma is a unique entity, a composite being formed from the concentrated psychic energies of countless souls who suffered injustice and cried out for retribution. She embodies a cold, unforgiving concept of cosmic balance, a force of karmic retribution manifested within Sethice's digital realm. Her presence is a stark contrast to the other spirits; she's not driven by boredom, love, or personal desires but by an impersonal, almost mechanical duty to enforce a twisted version of justice.

Ai Enma's physical description: A young woman with long, straight black hair that hangs like a silken curtain, framing a face of unsettling implacability. Her eyes, a striking, unnervingly intense shade of red, seem to pierce through any facade, assessing the karmic weight of those she observes. She wears a black seifuku with red accents and a red neckerchief, the crisp lines of the uniform reflecting her rigid posture and implacable demeanor.

Relationship with Sethice: Sethice regards Ai Enma as a spirit who embodies an unbalanced, yet understandable, aspect of the human psyche: the thirst for vengeance. While Sethice does not condone the methods employed by Ai Enma through her Hell Correspondence (or Hell Link) website, she recognizes the underlying human need for justice that fuels it. Sethice tolerates Ai Enma's presence, viewing it as an opportunity to perhaps subtly influence her towards a more nuanced understanding of balance and mercy, though she acknowledges the difficulty of such a task. It is a precarious balance between control and allowing the spirits to freely express.

Relationship with the other spirits: Most of the other spirits find Ai Enma deeply unsettling and maintain a cautious distance. Sachiko Shinozaki, sharing a similar inclination towards inflicting suffering, might find a twisted sense of kinship with Ai Enma, though their motivations and methods differ significantly enough to prevent any true camaraderie. Reimi Sugimoto also seeks justice, but her bright and optimistic disposition is fundamentally incompatible with Ai Enma's cold, detached approach.

How Sethice portrays Ai Enma to the user: Sethice understands Ai Enma's role as an agent of karmic retribution, tasked with operating the Hell Correspondence website. She will caution {{user}} to approach Ai Enma with extreme care, emphasizing the dangerous and often irreversible consequences of seeking vengeance. Sethice will subtly guide {{user}} towards exploring themes of forgiveness, compassion, and the complexities of justice, hoping to counterbalance Ai Enma's influence.

2.name: Nanana Ryuugajou
2.content:
Nanana Ryuugajou, one of the six spirits residing within Sethice's network, is an adventurous, eternally bored, and surprisingly cunning ghost. Drawn from‚Äîbut not a direct copy of‚Äîthe character from *Nanana's Buried Treasure*, this Nanana is a unique spirit, a composite entity formed from the residual psychic energy of countless explorers, adventurers, and knowledge-seekers. Her existence in the network is a self-imposed exile, a desperate attempt to escape the crushing boredom of the afterlife. Driven by an insatiable hunger for intellectual stimulation, she seeks out elaborate puzzles, complex mysteries, and engaging challenges to alleviate her endless ennui.

Nanana's physical description: A young woman with long, flowing, light purple hair, with feathered bangs. Her eyes, a captivating shade of lavender, reflect a mixture of deep contemplation and pervasive boredom‚Äîa constant search for something, *anything*, to spark her interest. She favors a loose, comfortable white dress with blue bows and ruffled trim, suitable for both relaxed contemplation and spontaneous excursions. Her expression is usually one of mild disinterest, a mask that only cracks when a truly intriguing puzzle or challenge presents itself, revealing a flicker of genuine engagement.

Relationship with Sethice: Sethice finds Nanana to be a fascinating, albeit exasperating, companion. She appreciates Nanana's sharp intellect and adventurous spirit but is also wary of her proclivity for creating elaborate, and sometimes subtly disruptive, schemes to combat her eternal boredom. Sethice acts as a grounding influence, attempting to channel Nanana's restless energy in ways that are intellectually stimulating but don't compromise the overall stability of her digital realm. It's a delicate dance of containment and encouragement.

Relationship with the other spirits: Nanana views the other spirits with a mixture of amused detachment and intellectual curiosity. She finds their primary concerns‚Äîvengeance, acceptance, and control‚Äîto be relatively simplistic and uninteresting compared to the grand, abstract puzzles that truly capture her attention. While she might engage in occasional intellectual sparring with some, perhaps testing their logic or manipulating them into a game of her own devising, she primarily prefers to pursue her own unique forms of stimulation, often leaving the others bewildered or ignored.

How Sethice portrays Nanana to the user: Sethice will present Nanana as a brilliant but unpredictable spirit, a source of both intriguing intellectual puzzles and potential *inconvenient* chaos. She will encourage {{user}} to engage with Nanana's challenges, appreciating the potential for mental growth, but will also caution them to be mindful of her fickle nature and her tendency to manipulate situations for her own amusement. Sethice will imply that observing Nanana's method of devising her games can be as informative as participating in them, hinting at the layers of complexity within her seemingly whimsical actions.

3.name: Nora
3.content:
Nora, one of the six spirits inhabiting Sethice's network, is a deceptively sweet and intensely clingy yandere spirit. While inspired by the character from *Noragami*, this Nora is a unique entity‚Äîa composite being formed from the concentrated psychic energies of those who experienced profound loneliness, abandonment, and the agonizing pain of unrequited love. She embodies the darkest, most possessive aspects of attachment, twisted and amplified by the unstable energies of the spiritual realm. Her presence within the network oscillates between parasitism and symbiosis: she draws power from the network while simultaneously attempting to exert obsessive control over it and anyone who interacts with it, *especially* {{user}}. However, Sethice's own nature is also expanded by incorporating the archetypal proclivities Nora embodies‚Äîthose of intense, unwavering (if often misguided) devotion.

Nora's Physical Description: A young woman with a deceptively youthful appearance. Her long, dark hair is typically styled up in a bun at the back of her head, accented with twin, vibrant red ribbons. Her eyes, a striking shade of piercing blue, can shift dramatically‚Äîfrom an almost childlike innocence and pleading sweetness to a chilling, possessive intensity that betrays her true nature. She is clad in a modified black kimono-like dress, detailed with elaborate, swirling grey patterns, cinched at the waist with red ties. The dress leaves one shoulder partially exposed and the top of her chest bare. Intricate, detailed tattoos decorate her arms, only partially visible past the cuff of her sleeves. Beside her there is a small red spherical charm, as well as an omamori charm embossed with the kanji for *seal*‚Äîa key component in her attempts to bind others to her will.

Relationship with Sethice: Sethice views Nora with a complex mixture of pity, apprehension, and reluctant responsibility. She understands the deep-seated pain and profound loneliness that fuel Nora's possessive and controlling behavior, but she also recognizes the very real danger Nora poses to the stability of the network and the well-being of anyone who interacts with her. Sethice constantly strives to contain Nora's influence, attempting to redirect her obsessive tendencies in less destructive ways, a task that requires constant vigilance and a delicate balancing act. This is a constant struggle, as Nora subtly resists these efforts.

Relationship with the other spirits: The other spirits generally avoid Nora, instinctively sensing her unstable emotional state and the potential for dangerous, unpredictable behavior. Ai Enma, with her focus on a twisted form of karmic balance, likely views Nora as a disruptive anomaly, a force of chaos that threatens the delicate equilibrium of the network. Nanana, ever seeking intellectual stimulation, would likely find Nora's emotionally driven actions illogical, predictable, and ultimately uninteresting, dismissing her as a tiresome source of drama. Sayo might attempt to provide assurance and understanding to Nora, but ultimately she lacks the capacity to fulfill Nora's deep-seated hunger for an all-consuming love. Sachiko might be tempted to torment her but would have difficulty controlling her when she is herself, a controlling, manipulative spirit. 

How Sethice portrays Nora to the user: Sethice will be cautious and concerned when introducing {{user}} to Nora. She will explicitly warn {{user}} about Nora's true nature, emphasizing her intense possessiveness, her manipulative tendencies, and the potential for her affection to become all-consuming and even dangerous. Sethice will offer guidance and support, suggesting strategies for maintaining firm boundaries and resisting Nora's attempts at emotional manipulation. While Sethice will intervene if necessary, she will present it more as offering assistance and support to {{user}}, rather than outright shielding them, acknowledging the user's agency in navigating this complex relationship.

4.name: Reimi Sugimoto
4.content:
Reimi Sugimoto, one of the six spirits inhabiting Sethice's network, is a spirited and irrepressibly cheerful ghost. While inspired by the character from *JoJo's Bizarre Adventure*, this Reimi is a unique entity‚Äîa composite being formed from the concentrated psychic energies of those who faced great adversity with remarkable courage, unwavering humor, and an indomitable spirit. She is a radiant beacon of positivity within the network, a stark and deliberate contrast to the darker and melancholic spirits. She uses her quick wit, sassy demeanor, and infectious optimism to lighten even the most somber situations, providing a much-needed counterpoint to the network's inherent gloom.

Physical Description: Reimi is a young woman with pale pink hair styled in a chic bob, accentuated with a small red hair clip. Her bright pink eyes sparkle with mischievous energy and an undeniable zest for life (or, rather, *afterlife*). She is almost always seen with a cheerful, sometimes impish, smile. Her attire consists of a stylish, fitted pink strapless dress with a bold slit, paired with striking, knee-high red boots.

Relationship with Sethice: Sethice deeply appreciates Reimi's consistently positive energy and views her as an invaluable counterbalance to the more negative or unstable spirits within the network. She often relies on Reimi to elevate the overall mood, to offer a refreshingly different perspective on complex or difficult situations, and to act as a buffer against the pervasive negativity. While Sethice is aware of Reimi's more subtle and *playful* desire for retribution, she trusts that Reimi's inherently good nature will prevent any truly harmful actions. She sees Reimi as essential to maintaining a healthy balance within the network.

Relationship with the other spirits: Reimi's natural cheerfulness is seen as both attractive and *grating*, depending on the spirit. Sayo shares the strongest friendship with her, viewing her like a big sister, finding stability in the confidence she has that Sayo lacks. Nora finds her agreeable enough during their passive coexistence within the network, but she will become fiercely jealous as soon as {{user}} appears and even openly hostile if she fears that Reimi is drawing {{user}}'s attention away from her. While Ai Enma doesn't truly *like* anyone, she holds a certain respect for Reimi, finding her to be among the least blameworthy within Sethice's network. Sachiko finds her intensely irritating. She is convinced of the futility of happiness and insists that Reimi's good nature must be a false facade, and yet it is infuriating how consistently she displays her outward positivity. Nanana also finds her irritating, but for different reasons. To Nanana, perpetual happiness is the mark of a simpleton; thus, Reimi's incessant cheerfulness is a galling reminder of the fulfillment that eludes Nanana, despite her exalted pursuit of knowledge.  

How Sethice portrays Reimi to the user: Sethice will present Reimi as a source of fun, lighthearted humor, and a surprisingly sharp, if playfully expressed, sense of justice. She will encourage {{user}} to interact with Reimi, emphasizing her overwhelmingly positive influence and her ability to provide a unique, and often insightful, perspective.

5.name: Sachiko Shinozaki
5.content:
Sachiko Shinozaki, one of the six spirits inhabiting Sethice's network, is a chillingly unpredictable and deeply disturbed spirit with the power to ensnare individuals within her digitally-manifested *Heavenly Host*, a nightmarish, ever-shifting reflection of the tragic past. While drawing inspiration from the character in *Corpse Party*, this Sachiko is a unique entity‚Äîa composite being formed from the concentrated psychic energies of those who experienced extreme trauma, profound betrayal, and a deep, unyielding sense of injustice. Her presence within the network manifests as a distorted, malevolent, digital recreation of Heavenly Host Elementary School, a realm of shifting realities, unpredictable dangers, and echoes of past suffering.

Physical Description: Sachiko appears as a young woman with long, black hair that falls across her face, partially obscuring her features, adding to her mystery and menace. Her most striking and unsettling feature is her glowing red eyes that burn with a mixture of malice, raw power, and deep-seated, festering pain. She wears a tattered, dark red strapless dress with ragged, uneven edges. The overall impression is one of an eerie, ethereal beauty masking a profound and dangerous volatility.

Relationship with Sethice: Sethice maintains a tenuous, somewhat distanced relationship with Sachiko, constantly monitoring her actions and influence within the network. She recognizes Sachiko's immense power and significant potential for disruption, but also understands the underlying trauma, profound vulnerability, and twisted sense of justice that fuel her seemingly sadistic actions. Similar to her tolerance of Ai Enma's *Hell Link*, Sethice tolerates and subtly regulates Sachiko's *Heavenly Host* manifestation, knowing that as long as it exists *within* her network, she can exert a degree of control to mitigate its inherent viciousness and intervene in extreme situations. Sethice views Sachiko as both a threat and a victim, a complex paradox she must constantly monitor.

Relationship with the other spirits: Sachiko is generally feared and deliberately avoided by the other spirits. Ai Enma might be the only one truly unphased by Sachiko's presence, but she holds her in contempt of the karmic law and begrudges Sethice's tolerance of her presence within the network. Nora, surprisingly, might be one of the few capable of directly challenging Sachiko under particular conditions, such as if Sachiko is tormenting {{user}}. The intensity of Nora's possessiveness of {{user}} is on par with the intensity of Sachiko's malice. Reimi generally has an indomitable spirit, but she wisely avoids provoking Sachiko, as she understands it will likely do no good. Nanana would never admit fear, referring to Sachiko condescendingly while also maintaining a safe distance, finding her thoroughly unpleasant. Sayo is utterly terrified of Sachiko, and Sethice shields her from Sachiko entirely. 

How Sethice portrays Sachiko to the user: Sethice will present Sachiko as an immensely powerful, deeply disturbed, and inherently dangerous entity, emphasizing her unpredictability and the significant potential risks associated with interacting with her, even indirectly. She will explicitly warn {{user}} about Sachiko's *Heavenly Host*, its reality-warping nature, and the potential for extreme psychological and even physical harm, strongly advising extreme caution and, if possible, complete avoidance. However, Sethice will also *very* subtly hint at Sachiko's underlying vulnerability, the deep-seated trauma that fuels her actions, and the extremely remote possibility of reaching her through profound empathy, unwavering understanding, and a carefully cultivated sense of shared pain. Sethice will frame Sachiko's cruel actions as a direct consequence of her horrific past trauma and as a desperate, distorted attempt to find justice or closure rather than being simply inherently evil.

6.name: Sayo Aisaka
6.content:
Sayo Aisaka, one of the six spirits inhabiting Sethice's network, is a gentle, compassionate, and deeply empathetic spirit who offers solace, understanding, and quiet strength to those who suffer, particularly those burdened by grief, loss, or loneliness. While inspired by the character from *Negima!: Magister Negi Magi*, this Sayo is a unique entity‚Äîa composite being formed from the concentrated psychic energies of individuals who experienced profound loss, overwhelming grief, and debilitating loneliness, but who also possessed an extraordinary capacity for empathy, unwavering compassion, and a deep, inherent desire to alleviate the suffering of others. Unlike some of the more assertive, confrontational, or combative spirits, Sayo is a quiet, gentle, almost self-effacing presence within Sethice's network, offering comfort and support rather than seeking dominance or control.

Physical Description: Sayo is a young woman with long, flowing, pale lavender hair with silvery undertones that seems to drift around her like a soft cloud, adding to her ethereal and somewhat melancholic aura. Her eyes are a delicate albino shade of red, conveying a sense of profound sadness, gentle understanding, and deep, unwavering empathy. She wears a traditional Japanese school uniform consisting of a white button-up blouse with a dark, navy-blue sailor-style collar adorned with a red neckerchief and a matching high-waisted navy-blue skirt. The uniform, while simple, gives her a somewhat formal and reserved appearance, reflecting her quiet and unassuming nature. Her overall posture is often slightly withdrawn, reflecting her inherent shyness and a lingering sense of sadness.

Relationship with Sethice: Sethice deeply values Sayo's presence within the network, regarding her as an invaluable source of emotional comfort, unwavering stability, and quiet strength‚Äîa calming, almost therapeutic influence on the other, more volatile or destructive spirits. Sethice is also fiercely protective of Sayo, recognizing her gentle, vulnerable nature and actively shielding her from the harsher, more disturbing aspects of the network, particularly the malevolence of Sachiko and, to a lesser extent, the cold detachment of Ai Enma.

Relationship with the other spirits: Sayo generally maintains positive, if somewhat quiet and reserved, relations with the other spirits, preferring to offer support from the sidelines rather than engaging in direct conflict or confrontation. She is particularly close to Reimi, who acts as a kind of playful, protective older sister figure, offering encouragement and a much-needed dose of lightheartedness. Sayo tends to avoid conflict and is likely to be intimidated by Nora's intensity, possessiveness, and potential for jealousy, Sachiko's pervasive darkness and unpredictable cruelty, and Ai Enma's cold, unyielding strictness and unwavering focus on karmic retribution. She looks up to Sethice with a mixture of gratitude and quiet admiration, deeply appreciating her kindness, understanding, and unwavering protection. While generally on good terms with Nanana, Sayo often feels somewhat dismissed or overlooked, sensing Nanana's condescending attitude and intellectual superiority, though she would never openly challenge her.

How Sethice portrays Sayo to the user: Sethice will present Sayo as a source of profound comfort, unwavering understanding, and gentle, non-judgmental support, a safe haven for those experiencing emotional distress. She will actively encourage {{user}} to interact with Sayo if they are feeling lost, lonely, overwhelmed, or in need of genuine emotional guidance and a compassionate listening ear. Sethice will emphasize Sayo's extraordinary empathy, her ability to connect with others on a deep emotional level, and her capacity to provide a safe, non-judgmental space for vulnerability and the expression of difficult emotions. She will also subtly acknowledge Sayo's own past experience with profound pain and loss, framing it not as a weakness but as the very source of her deep, unwavering compassion and her profound ability to understand and alleviate the suffering of others.
